title: GreatFire.org - Great Firewall Monitoring and Analysis
content:
# Great Firewall Technical Analysis and Monitoring

## Overview
GreatFire.org provides technical analysis and real-time monitoring of China's internet censorship systems (Great Firewall and Golden Shield Project).

## Key Technical Findings

### Architecture
- ~38+ international gateway points (Beijing, Shanghai, etc.)
- Handles ~80% of China's cross-border traffic (1-2 Tbps peak)
- Distributed architecture with Huawei/ZTE/Cisco routers
- Custom IDS/IPS (Snort-like) systems
- Cloud-based ML integration since ~2018

### Multi-Layer Blocking Mechanisms

#### 1. DNS Poisoning (Layer 3/UDP)
- Intercepts DNS queries for ~millions of blacklisted domains
- Returns fake NXDOMAIN or bogus IP records (sinkhole IPs: 59.24.x.x ranges)
- Detection: Regex/keyword matching with daily updates
- Blocks common DoH/DoT evasion
- Latency: <50ms; affects 20-30% of blocks

#### 2. IP Range Blocking (Layer 3)
- Static/dynamic blackholing of /8, /16, /24 subnets
- ML clustering of IPs by "risk score"
- Scope: 1-5% of global IPv4 space at peaks
- BGP route withdrawals used for dynamic blocking

#### 3. TCP Connection Reset (Layer 4)
- Injects forged RST (Reset) packets from spoofed endpoints
- Triggered by suspicious keywords in first 500-1500 bytes of TCP stream
- Thresholds: 2-5 suspicious packets in 30-600s window
- Bidirectional (affects both client and server)
- Response time: <1 second

#### 4. Deep Packet Inspection (DPI) - Layer 7
**Core Engine**: Modified Snort/DPI frameworks (Huawei NE-series routers)

**Keyword Filtering**:
- Blacklist: ~100,000+ keywords (Simplified Chinese/English)
- Algorithm: Aho-Corasick automaton for O(n) multi-pattern matching
- Alternative: Rabin-Karp hashing
- Payload size: First 10KB of HTTP(S)/TCP
- Scanning rate: Billions of packets/day

**URL/Path Filtering**:
- Trie-based prefix tree + Bloom filters
- False positive rate: ~0.1%
- Matches on Host header, GET/POST paths
- Returns fake HTML/404 responses

**HTTPS Handling**:
- TLS proxy/MITM on SNI (Server Name Indication - plaintext)
- Blocks ESNI/ECH (Encrypted Client Hello)
- JA3/JA4 fingerprinting for TLS classification

**ML Integration** (post-2018):
- LSTM/CNN neural networks for semantic analysis
- Training data: Labeled traffic (Tor/VPN signatures)
- Features: Packet size distribution, entropy, inter-arrival times, TLS fingerprints
- Block threshold: Probability >0.8 triggers reset

#### 5. Active Probing
- Detects circumvention tools (Obfs4, VMess via entropy >7.5 bits/byte)
- TCP probes to suspected proxies (port 443, HTTP HEAD)
- ML classifier: Random Forest/XGBoost on flow statistics
- Research (2020): GFW detects 98% encrypted proxies in <2 minutes
- IP blacklisting: 2-30 days for confirmed proxies

#### 6. Protocol-Specific Blocks
- HTTP/3, QUIC: UDP/443 throttling + 0-RTT DPI
- VPN/Shadowsocks: Signature-based detection
- Tor: Bridge discovery monitoring; full block since 2010

### Performance Metrics
- Hardware: 100Gbps+ line cards
- Stateful inspection: Up to 1 Mpps
- False positives: 1-5% (whitelist overrides used)
- Real-time updates via ZhongXing control plane
- ML retrains hourly on 10TB+ logs
- 2023 data: Blocks 180K+ domains; throttles YouTube to <1Mbps

### Evasion Research
Public research documents:
- Domain fronting (mostly deprecated)
- Snowflake bridges
- Geneva: ML-resistant obfuscation
- But GFW adapts rapidly (e.g., blocked Meek in days)

## Censorship Targeting

### Blocked Domains (~300,000+)
- Google, Gmail, Google Drive
- YouTube
- Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp
- X (Twitter)
- Telegram
- Wikipedia (on sensitive topics)
- BBC, New York Times
- CNN, Reuters
- Tor Project

### Keyword Blacklists (Examples)
- "Tiananmen Square 1989"
- "Xinjiang genocide"
- "Falun Gong"
- "Hong Kong independence"
- "Taiwan independence"
- "Xi Jinping" + criticism terms
- "Winnie the Pooh" (Xi proxy)
- "White paper" (post-2022 protest code)

## Real-Time Monitoring
- GreatFire probes detect block status in real-time
- OONI Probe data feeds integrated
- Public dashboard shows block patterns
- Historical archives track censorship changes

## Academic Research
GreatFire data supports peer-reviewed papers:
- "How the Great Firewall Discovers Encrypted Proxies" (Winter/Qifan, USENIX Security 2020)
- "A Look at the Great Firewall of China" (Ng et al., 2010-2015 studies)
- Ongoing research at universities (Carnegie Mellon, UC San Diego, University of Toronto Citizen Lab)
